title: Introduction

author: Marianne Ping Huang, School of Communication and Culture, University of Aarhus

segmentation: Tonya and Henrik thank you for having me.
So as I mentioned I am.
I'm Co heading the sort of the part of Daria which is for research and education communities.
Amco heading with the Gatti's, Benado and sort of the importance of, I think really the course registry is an important service for us.
In Darien for the DH communities as such across Europe.

And also I think in a broader sense for teaching humanities and teaching social Sciences, it's one of the old working groups that has now turned into a sustained service actually, and I think what the coordinators have, like Antonio, will be asking you today is actually to get used to using this service.
And I think I might, you know.
Intervene a bit with what you were going to say Tonya.
So this is how the map looks currently and you can see there are quite a few entries or courses.
And taught throughout Europe.
They also like still areas and territories to be filled out, which is like white spots on the map.
Um, so that's where some of you come in today.

It's it's a map based environment and what you basically get is information on the DH courses of a rather brought variety which is being taught in higher education throughout Europe and the courses are like sustained courses.
There are courses that is recurrent.
So you can search for location for institution for Easy TS credits and for the academic level and agree.
And you can also search more, sort of.
Seem based on activity based.
Then, based on to Dara.
Then
I think the important thing about this is actually the audiences that this course registry is for is.
So we have obviously an audience of students and researchers that will.
Now might attendant forces.
Cora from back sure has sort of experience of.
Having an online course now and with students on the level that the course is sort of given for, but also with professors that wants to learn to use Python.
So you might get actually a mixed audience searching this.
And you would also, obviously because I'll show you there are some small statistics.
Embedded with the registry.
So you might also your now do this mapping of the European courses to see what are the spread in in in themes, objectives, levels and so on.
Obviously also lecturers, teachers looking for how do they teach my course in other institutions.
Who's teaching it?
How can we maybe get in touch and share good practices?
And being a former Vice team, this is really important to me so that that institutions and head up studies.
Get an opportunity to attract and facilitate student mobility and also stock mobility.
But student mobility.
Actually, if you are having a DH area or part of your study, entire study program is.
Have DH, you might also get you know students from archaeology wanting to do digital archaeology, and you can use this and say you could go there.
You could like have your credits there.
You could come back or you can attract students from other institutions on an exchange basis to come to your institution.
So I think that's the courses that you can find here.
This actually they have.
They are sustained.
They also within sort of the European qualification framework.
I think that's important.
It's a guarantee to our students that they can actually move around and get the credits.
That is that will be recognized with their own institutions within their own degree program.
That's really important, but it also gives us an opportunity to enhance and strengthen.
What is one of the objectives for the area actually to twin Hans teaching and education within this area and also to take DH methods?
DH philosophes into say humanities and social Sciences, broadly speaking.
And last thing I'll just show you because when.
You go to the course register.

You might find statistics and this is sort of the first you meet to see how the courses that are now on the map, how they spread out in like disciplines that you will be able to recognize and and there are few other statistics.
And I actually think that's really interesting, but probably that's because an old Vice Dean for education.
So what's very good about today is actually that you will get your hands dirty.
You'll try to enter course and be guided through that.
Thank you.
Thank you for having me.
